title: What Is ChatGPT Doing … and Why Does It Work?

last_post.content:
Given some of the info in this ( https://writings.stephenwolfram.com/2023/02/what-is-chatgpt-doing-and-why-does-it-work/ ) very helpful summary of ChatGPT stuff, I'm starting to think ChatGPT's simple sentence style is not the result of deliberate training for readability and SEO but actually something about the model itself.

The network can figure out the rules of English syntax enough to get by but not enough to consistently generate longer, more complex sentences.

It's tempting to see a connection between this and what *humans* find more readable.

title: ChatGPT sometimes makes up facts. For one law prof, it went too far.

last_post.content:
Asked for examples of sexual harassment at law schools, ChatGPT named a GW law prof accused of touching a student on a class trip to Alaska, citing a 2018 Washington Post story.

The law prof is real. The rest was made up.

We wrote about what happens when AIs lie about you: https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2023/04/05/chatgpt-lies/

title: ‘Thousands of Dollars for Something I Didn’t Do’

last_post.content:
A well-reported story from @kashhill and Ryan Mac about the errors of face recognition technology:

https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/31/technology/facial-recognition-false-arrests.html

As my colleague Nate Wessler says, “This is a chilling reminder of how dangerous face recognition technology is in the hands of police."

But I have a few other thoughts as well.

While the technology in this case is novel, the kafkaesque nature of the penal system is not. This man was arrested and stayed in jail for 6 days and didn't know why. It cost thousands of dollars to get a lawyer, and he missed 6 days of work. He could have been fired, not only missed being paid. That alone for many people would be a crushing economic blow.

And don't miss the inhumanity. Did no one bother to talk to the man and ask, "have you ever been to this state?" Or ask if he could prove he wasn't there when the crime happened, like because he was at work? Or did they just cage him?

The cruelty of the system is a big part of why the tech is so dangerous. You have to fix both.

title: I think I’m not alone that Mastodon is giving me the ick

last_post.content:
I agree in many ways with this critique from @andy of Mastodon's current state of affairs: https://andy-bell.co.uk/i-think-im-not-alone-that-mastodon-is-giving-me-the-ick/

I'm not angry at the journalists who've chosen to remain on Twitter despite its CEO's loud contempt for them -- though I do think it's fair to say that they are supporting him by pouring their work into his site.

Rather, I'm disappointed with them. Deeply disappointed. I hope they will reconsider.

#opensource #TLS #PKI #infosec

@tree @tchambers Hey Tristan, you mentioned you wanted a better UX for media.

Have you tried Pixelfed? (@pixelfed https://pixelfed.social/ )

It's optimised for photo and video. It's on the Fediverse, meaning you can interact with everyone on Mastodon. You can view text-only posts from Mastodon if you want (settings -> Timelines -> Show text-only posts).

The developers are actively working on it, including releasing a native iOS and Android app due to hit the app stores in late-April/early May.

The other thing that's worth trying if you haven't already is some of the third-party apps for iOS and Android. Personally, I find Tooot for Android is a much better UX than the native Mastodon app.

The notes from the various #Fediforum sessions last week are on-line now. Lots of interesting tidbits there.

Video from the speed demos is still being edited. Stay tuned.

https://fediforum.org/

Knitted origami
Elizabeth L. Wilmer

"Techniques are presented for embedding horizontal, vertical, and45◦diagonal crease lines into garter stitch knitted fabric. While theseare mostly based on standard lace knitting stitches, the horizon-tal creases use double-cable-crossed elongated stitches in a non-standard way. This crease library suffices to knit a model of a squaretwist, a foundational origami tessellation unit."

title: SoK: On the Impossible Security of Very Large Foundation Models

last_post.content:
On the large AI models, this preprint synthesises what we know so far https://arxiv.org/abs/2209.15259

In short: it is mathematically impossible to have AIs combining the following properties:

1) High number of parameters
2) Robustness to poisoning (e.g. fake data)
3) Privacy-preserving

title: Constitutional AI: Harmlessness from AI Feedback

last_post.content:
"As AI systems become more capable, we would like to enlist their help to supervise other AIs. We experiment with methods for training a harmless AI assistant through self-improvement, without any human labels identifying harmful outputs. The only human oversight is provided through a list of rules or principles, and so we refer to the method as 'Constitutional AI'."

[2212.08073] Constitutional AI: Harmlessness from AI Feedback
https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.08073#

title: The Prospect of an AI Winter

last_post.content:
“Why are autonomous vehicles (henceforth, AVs) still not reliable enough to be widely used? I suspect because driving a car is not a single task, but a task complex, a bundle of many different subtasks with varying inputs. The overall reliability of driving is highly dependent on the performance of those subtasks, and failure in any one of them could lead to overall failure.”

The 2023 @WebAIM Milion report is out: https://webaim.org/projects/million/
There is progress, but, zero surprise, main errors are still:
- low contrast
- missing alt text for images
- empty links (why? how??)
- missing form input labels (seriously, devs, it's not that hard!!!)
- empty button (again, why?)
- missing document language

title: [PDF] The Semantic Reader Project: Augmenting Scholarly Documents through AI-Powered Interactive Reading Interfaces | Semantic Scholar

last_post.content: Researchers - imagine a vastly better reading experience than your plain PDF, with improved comprehensibility, accessibility, and ability to triage. If that excites you, take a look at this collection of work on the future of reading interfaces for scholarly papers! https://www.semanticscholar.org/reader/67a5bacb00651dbe0dd9ef2a563fe64b19b2c6a8
GRID WORLD by Alexander Miller https://alex.miller.garden/grid-world/ #grid #graphics #retro #javascript

title: Pythia: A Suite for Analyzing Large Language Models Across Training and Scaling

last_post.content:
RT @BlancheMinerva@twitter.com

Have you ever wanted to do an experiment on LLMs and found that none of the existing model suites met your needs? At @AiEleuther@twitter.com we got tired of this happening and so designed a model suite that centers enabling scientific research as its primary goal

https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01373

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/BlancheMinerva/status/1643411683858169861

title: Study: SARS-CoV-2, the virus causing COVID-19, can alter genome structure of our cells - Anesthesiology, Critical Care and Pain Medicine

last_post.content:
... unknown pathogen causes during an infection is a *lower bound* to the actual harms. It's not even centered on the expectation value, because you can expect to learn more about the harms in the future.

People do not understand this intentional bias in scientific research. And people make risk decisions around a *lower bound* for risk, not around *expected value* of risk.

One data point about underestimating COVID harms:

https://med.uth.edu/anesthesiology/2023/03/23/study-sars-cov-2-the-virus-causing-covid-19-can-alter-genome-structure-of-our-cells/

title: Deep time is, like, really, really deep, man | National Center for Science Education

last_post.content:
The history of Earth as the length of a human’s outstretched arm - representing 4.5 billion years of time.

At this scale, humans emerged so recently that we could be filed off from a microscopic slice at the very tip of a fingernail.

Infographic by Katie Scott from original article in Nautilus. Details at https://ncse.ngo/deep-time-really-really-deep-man #space #time #science #SharedPlanet

title: Régi magyar számítógépek - Hungarian Old Computers

last_post.content:
This obscure (to me, at least?) Hungarian microcomputer represents the correct ratio between the keyboard and the display.

Via the amazing and seemingly endless https://www.holdcomputers.com/

title: TPU v4: An Optically Reconfigurable Supercomputer for Machine Learning with Hardware Support for Embeddings

last_post.content:
TPU v4: An Optically Reconfigurable Supercomputer for Machine Learning with Hardware Support for Embeddings

TPU v4 outperforms TPU v3 by 2.1x, and The TPU v4 pod is 4x larger at 4096 chips and thus ~10x faster overall.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01433

title: How to design architecture for wildlife | BUILT ECOLOGIES: ARCHITECTURE AND ENVIRONMENT

last_post.content:
And I missed this Joyce Hwang episode in the series last year!

Hwang "studies the ways that wildlife–birds, bees, and bats–find shelter in the built environment. 'They’re not extracting resources. They’re able to work with what they have.'"

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sRwYp4F-4lk

An underrated feature of VSCode for #rstats is unlimited R terminals. Here I can casually work through my check() output (right) in a separate interactive session (left). I do the same with with test output.

A simple time / frustration saver, over being locked to a single R session.

I wrote about another application of this here: https://milesmcbain.micro.blog/2022/10/18/are-you-data.html

title: GitHub - gdbassett/slightly-more-than-minimal-blockly: attempt to use blockly with wasm-r

last_post.content:
Not much, but it's a start: #RStats #WebR #blockly. **BIG** thanks to @hrbrmstr. I wouldn't have made it this far w/o him.

(This has been something I've wanted to do for years, but couldn't until #WebR. Imagine if you could load your own breach data as VERIS, filter/mutate it to get the subset you want, then analyze it. All in the browser w/o knowing #rstats

Still *very* early, but the PoC works!

EDIT: It's not pretty, but I've shared the code at https://github.com/gdbassett/slightly-more-than-minimal-blockly.

💚 Bob was a kind person who lived more life in 43 years than most would do in 430. I will miss him and his magic.

https://publicobject.com/2023/04/05/bob-bent-the-universe/

#CrazyBob

Book release!! 📘🥳

"Deep Learning and Scientific Computing with R torch" by Sigrid Keydana

Freely available online, this book introduces torch basics, shares deep-learning use cases & shows how to use torch for general topics, such as matrix computations & the Fourier Transform.

Blog post about the release: https://blogs.rstudio.com/ai/posts/2023-04-05-deep-learning-scientific-computing-r-torch/

e-book: https://taylorfrancis.com/books/mono/10.1201/9781003275923/deep-learning-scientific-computing-torch-sigrid-keydana

Order a print copy: https://routledge.com/Deep-Learning-and-Scientific-Computing-with-R-torch/Keydana/p/book/9781032231396

Free online edition: https://skeydan.github.io/Deep-Learning-and-Scientific-Computing-with-R-torch/

#rstats #torch #DL #ML

title: NPR Was Twitter’s Example Of What Should NOT Be Labeled ‘State-Affiliated Media.’ Then Musk Added The Label And Retconned The Policy

last_post.content:
@mmasnick has an outstanding piece re Musk labeling NPR as “state-affiliated” media. I highly recommend it.

Masnick correctly notes that while all of this may seem silly, it’s not. It’s a glaring example of how Musk keeps choosing his petty ego over serious issues of information integrity, and is actually harming trust & safety.

“It’s arbitrary, it’s stupid, it’s petty, it’s vindictive. And it’s everything that’s wrong with Twitter 2.0 in one simple stupid snapshot.”
https://www.techdirt.com/2023/04/05/npr-was-twitters-example-of-what-should-not-be-labeled-state-affiliated-media-then-musk-added-the-label-and-retconned-the-policy/

OHAI, I am helping to organize a workshop on Generative AI and Law, to be held at ICML ’23. Here is the CFP:

https://genlaw.github.io

title: Private Planes and Luxury Yachts Aren’t Just Toys for the Ultrawealthy. They’re Also Huge Tax Breaks.

How the Ultrarich Claim Huge Tax Deductions on Their Private Jets and Luxury Yachts
--

#Taxes #IRS #Wealth #Boats #Planes #PrivateJets

I haven't yet had a chance to dig into this pre-print but I know from @elmahdi its been in the works for a while now, so looking forward to reading. Although I wouldn't call them foundation models. I'd call them multimodal pretrained models, or anything that doesn't confuse people further about them being close to foundational.
https://arxiv.org/pdf/2209.15259.pdf

If you are interested in #OnlineCommunities, you probably know about The WELL http://well.com , a forum that has been in continuous operation since 1985. It turns out that https://bigthink.com/the-well/ is trying to steal the name and a very close approximation of the WELL's logo (the swirl).

If you are interested in #OnlineCommunities, you probably know about The WELL http://well.com , a forum that has been in continuous operation since 1985. It turns out that https://bigthink.com/the-well/ is trying to steal the name and a very close approximation of the WELL's logo (the swirl).

A preprint that I've been working on for quite some time with the brilliant @raphaelmilliere is now available on ArXiv: The Vector Grounding Problem -
https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01481

In a nutshell, we argue that some large pretrained #ai models, especially those fine-tuned with #RLHF, have the features required to have internal representations and outputs imbued with intrinsic meaning.

We show this is in 3 steps. First, we argue that the traditional Symbol Grounding Problem for classical AI (...)

title: Klaus Teuber, Creator of the Board Game Catan, Dies at 70

last_post.content:
What a beautiful quote and life lesson from Klaus Teuber, inventor of Catan:

“There may have been a good balance between strategy and luck,” he said. “For example, roulette is only about luck, and chess is all about strategies. However, if you win in Catan, you think, ‘My strategy was good,’ and when you lose, you might think, ‘I was just out of luck.’ This is the same as life.”

#boardgames #catan

https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/05/business/klaus-teuber-dead.html?unlocked_article_code=y21UWYVSqxb3RatzPgvCpXAx7opMMWTfhJT8Jx1mmctlawTc42oqn34fEA5NLZwh-cgkzPW4gzAEyA28n3dba-kYPdKgNF8oAYuZBuz0vWEYrZpqh3YbrOgxLhTd7TNrj-NEdzENpqCvgSuNaubpXuKg0Wgj1LpbbM6yYgWEauY-kuwjTAVncE8DDR1RcuUX132rlAPgeaJcFVrcHQycc0cTbZZjvhefccDh9Jr3Qxc55UmjRzM6oKSVvbDQGZmW4DGVl212EYo5jEceNwwFCen9TZXQKoXwehIm4MenL64BjqnJ4rcUfSqQ5Tt-x0LwRxPRHE171mPgt84&smid=nytcore-ios-share&referringSource=articleShare

The Segment Anything project is really impressive. It's:

- a computer vision task: segment all areas in an image for any class of object & background.
- a paper describing the task, model and dataset
https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02643
- a very large dataset (11M images!):
https://segment-anything.com/dataset/index.html
- a model published as a running demo (the model runs in the browser):
https://segment-anything.com/demo

The dataset and model where co-developed (model in the loop) to iteratively improve both via active learning.

title: GitHub - andrewheiss/quarto-wordcount: Quarto extension for calculating accurate word counts

last_post.content: Counting words in #rstats markdown / #QuartoPub is hard because it's tricky to capture content like tables, captions, and references. @FrederikAust 's {rmdfiltr} works great for Rmd files, so I adapted it as a Quarto extension. Behold {quarto-wordcount}! https://github.com/andrewheiss/quarto-wordcount

title: New Directions in Book History | Book titles in this series

last_post.content: #Servicetoot: For those #histodons interested in #bookhistory, you might want to check the Hardcover-Sale of the (normally way too expensive) publisher PalgraveMacMillan. For example, all books and volumes of the series "New Directions in Book History" are 25 Euro, including my "Books in Motion in Early Modern Europe" and "Magical Manuscripts": https://link.springer.com/series/14749/books

title: Matan Hakim - Policy Data Scientist - Introducing rtrl - an R Package for RTL Languages

last_post.content:
Happy to announce that my first-ever #Rstats package, {rtlr}, was accepted to CRAN🥳 🥳 🥳

{rtlr} handles right-to-left languages with ease, so if you happen to be an :rstats: user working with RTL languages (such as Arabic, Persian or Hebrew) then this is definitely for you!

Read all about it in my (also first-ever) blog post, written with #Quarto:
https://matanhakim.org/posts/2023-04-05-rtlr-0-1-0/

(Boosts are welcome to reach as much RTL useRs as possible🙏 )
